docs.lead_paragraph: People in Australia and New Zealand consume more marijuana and amphetamines than anyone else in the world, research in The Lancet has concluded.

headline.main: Marijuana Use Most Rampant in Australia, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Marijuana Use Most Rampant in Australia, Study Finds

docs.snippet: People in Australia and New Zealand consume more marijuana and amphetamines than anyone else in the world, research in The Lancet has concluded.

docs.lead_paragraph: Brendan Cochrane had been, by and large, a model parolee. After serving 10 years for attempted murder, he started a video production business, moved into an apartment in Manhattan, got engaged and abstained from drugs and alcohol. But last year, after four years on parole, he found himself back in prison for six months.

headline.main: State Loosens Leash on Parolees, So Fewer Are Rejailed

docs.abstract: New York State revamps its policy on parolees, reducing the number that are returned to prison for minor parole violations; new guidelines sort parolees as low- or high-risk and tailor their supervision accordingly, in an effort to reduce recidivism rates. Photo (M)6
docs.snippet: Brendan Cochrane had been, by and large, a model parolee. After serving 10 years for attempted murder, he started a video production business, moved into an apartment in Manhattan, got engaged and abstained from drugs and alcohol.     But last year,...

headline.main: Rules May Help Parolees Avoid Jail for Small Errors
headline.print_headline: State Loosens Leash on Parolees, So Fewer Are Rejailed

docs.abstract: The state's new guidelines aim to keep parolees from returning to prison for minor infractions, but for one Harlem man, the changes came too late.
docs.snippet: The state's new guidelines aim to keep parolees from returning to prison for minor infractions, but for one Harlem man, the changes came too late.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration said the widespread use of cephalosporins may have contributed to the development of drug-resistant bacteria that infect humans.

headline.seo: F.D.A. Restricts Cephalosporin Antibiotics in Livestock
headline.main: Citing Drug Resistance, U.S. Restricts More Antibiotics for Livestock
headline.print_headline: Citing Drug Resistance, U.S. Restricts More Antibiotics for Livestock

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration announces that farmers and ranchers must restrict their use of a critical class of antibiotics in cattle, pigs, chickens and turkeys; say restrictions are necessary because such practices may have contributed to the growing threat in people of bacterial infections that are resistant to treatment.
docs.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration said the widespread use of cephalosporins may have contributed to the development of drug-resistant bacteria that infect humans.

docs.lead_paragraph: Contagion depends on a complex interplay between a virus and its victim, including where it enters the body, the types of cells in which it can reproduce and whether it can then escape.

headline.seo: An Explanation of How Avian Flu Spreads
headline.main: How Hard Would It Be for Avian Flu to Spread?
headline.print_headline: How Hard Would It Be For Avian Flu To Spread?

docs.abstract: Scientific opinion varies widely concerning dangers posed by a study in which avian influenza virus was genetically modified in order to make it more contagious; though unmodified virus has only infected 600 people since its discovery, unusually high mortality rate gives it the potential to eventually mutate into an unprecedented pandemic, alarming those concerned about what terrorists could do with the information.
docs.snippet: Contagion depends on a complex interplay between a virus and its victim, including where it enters the body, the types of cells in which it can reproduce and whether it can then escape.

byline.original: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. and DENISE GRADY

docs.lead_paragraph: Urine has a uniquely valuable role in medicine: It holds clues not just to what people eat and drink, but also to how well their bodies are functioning.

headline.seo: A Valuable Medical Tell-All Can Be Found in Urine
headline.main: A Medical Tell-All Can Be Found in Urine
headline.print_headline: A Medical Tell-All Can Be Found in Urine

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on the various medical uses of urine, which can give clues about dietary health and organ function.
docs.snippet: Urine has a uniquely valuable role in medicine: It holds clues not just to what people eat and drink, but also to how well their bodies are functioning.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon may have to come up with as much as $1 trillion in cuts if Congress follows through with deeper reductions. Make your own plan to reduce the budget.

headline.main: The Future Military: Your Budget Strategy

docs.lead_paragraph: In the battle to lose weight, and keep it off, our bodies are fighting against us.
docs.abstract: Tara Parker-Pope article highlights research done by University of Melbourne professor Dr Joseph Proietto on obesity, which was published in The New England Journal of Medicine and has caused a stir in the weight-loss community; Proietto and his colleagues have found that the human body continues to fight against weight loss long after dieting has stopped, and adds to a growing body of evidence that challenges conventional thinking about obesity.
docs.snippet: In the battle to lose weight, and keep it off, our bodies are fighting against us.
